claims.text: The last years have been the warmest since modern record-keeping began.
claims.context: NASA scientist discussing climate change effects.

claim_reports.claim_text: The last years have been the warmest since modern record-keeping began.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that the last years have been the warmest since modern record-keeping began, with multiple high-reliability sources confirming that the past decade, particularly from 2015 to 2024, has seen the highest temperatures recorded since 1880.

supports.title: Climate change: global temperature
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that the last decade has seen the warmest years since modern record-keeping began in 1880, with the past nine years being the warmest on record according to NASA's temperature analysis.
supports.snippet: The ten warmest years in the 175-year record have all occurred during the last decade (2015–2024).

supports.title: World of Change: Global Temperatures - NASA Science
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that the past nine years have been the warmest years since modern recordkeeping began in 1880, supporting the claim about recent temperature trends.
supports.snippet: The past nine years have been the warmest years since modern recordkeeping began in 1880. As the maps show, global warming does not mean temperatures rise ...

supports.title: WMO confirms 2024 as warmest year on record at about 1.55°C ...
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that the last decade, specifically from 2015 to 2024, has been the warmest years on record since modern record-keeping began in 1880, with a significant increase in global temperatures attributed to human activities.
supports.snippet: WMO confirms 2024 as warmest year on record at about 1.55°C above pre-industrial level · The past ten years 2015-2024 are the ten warmest years ...

supports.title: Earth's 10 Hottest Years on Record Are the Last 10
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that the last decade has been the warmest period since modern record-keeping began in 1880, with the past nine years being the hottest on record according to temperature analyses from NASA and other organizations.
supports.snippet: A report from the World Meteorological Organization confirms that 2024 was the hottest year on record and the first year to be more than 1.5 degrees Celsius ...

supports.title: Temperatures Rising: NASA Confirms 2024 Warmest Year on Record
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that 2024 is the warmest year on record since modern record-keeping began in 1880, and that the past decade has been the warmest overall.
supports.snippet: 2024 was Earth's warmest year since modern record-keeping began around 1880, and the past 10 consecutive years have been the warmest 10 on ...

transcript_data.text: Why does climate change matter? NASA We Asked a NASA Scientist. Well, it's happening. We look at the Earth from space and we measure it on the ground. And what we see is that the planet's climate is changing. The last years have been the warmest since modern record-keeping began. It's serious. Even a little change in temperature can have big effects. And we're seeing some of those effects now. Sea levels are rising. We're seeing more extreme events like heatwaves and heavy rainfall and wildfire. And we know that a lot of those effects are going to increase with more warming. These changes are impacting decisions that some people make every day, like a farmer thinking about what crops to grow or a homeowner thinking about flood risk. But there's hope. There are scientists at NASA and around the world that are researching this. We know more about our planet than we have ever before, and we learn more every day. So we know why climate is changing. We know that it's due to increasing greenhouse gases from human activity. We also have tools that can help us better understand and better prepare for future climate change. So we develop computer models that help us understand how much it might change in the future. And we're also developing technologies here at NASA and around the world that can help us limit future warming or respond to the warming that we're experiencing. So why does climate change matter? It's real. It's serious, and it's here. We Asked a NASA Scientist. NASA. A NASA 360 Production.
